chapterSummary.General: The Israelites multiply in Egypt, leading to their oppression by a new Pharaoh who fears their growing numbers. The midwives refuse to kill Hebrew boys, and Pharaoh commands all Hebrew boys to be thrown into the Nile.
chapterSummary.Non-Denominational: Focuses on God's preservation of His chosen people despite oppression, demonstrating His faithfulness to His promises and His ability to work through faithful servants like the midwives.
chapterSummary.Baptist: Emphasizes God's sovereign protection of His covenant people, showing His faithfulness to His promises and His ability to work through faithful servants who fear Him more than earthly rulers.
chapterSummary.Catholic: Highlights God's providential care for His chosen people, demonstrating His faithfulness to His promises and His ability to work through faithful servants who uphold the sanctity of life.
chapterSummary.Methodist: Focuses on God's preservation of His people through faithful servants, showing His commitment to justice and His ability to work through those who fear Him more than earthly powers.
chapterSummary.Lutheran: Emphasizes God's protection of His chosen people, demonstrating His faithfulness to His promises and His ability to work through faithful servants who uphold His commandments.
chapterSummary.Presbyterian: Stresses God's covenantal faithfulness to His people, showing His ability to preserve them through faithful servants who fear Him more than earthly authorities.
chapterSummary.Pentecostal: Highlights God's supernatural protection of His chosen people, demonstrating His power to work through faithful servants who fear Him more than earthly rulers.
chapterSummary.Anglican: Emphasizes God's providential care for His people, showing His faithfulness to His promises and His ability to work through faithful servants who uphold His commandments.
chapterSummary.Orthodox: Focuses on God's preservation of His chosen people, demonstrating His faithfulness to His promises and His ability to work through faithful servants who fear Him more than earthly powers.
